Message.Title: War Hero to Climate Hawk, good choice
Message.Msg: As Secretary of State, John Kerry Would Be a Climate Hawk —By Kate Sheppard | Mon Dec. 17, 2012 10:33 AM PST Over the weekend, various news outlets reported that President Obama is going to tap Sen. John Kerry to serve as the next Secretary of State. This is not much of a surprise, since the other reported leading candidate for the post, UN ambassador Susan Rice, withdrew herself from consideration last Thursday. For climate hawks, having Kerry at the helm at State would be very good news. Kerry is among the most fierce advocates for climate action in the Senate. Here he is in a floor speech from August talking about why climate change is "as significant a level of importance" as Syria and Iran: Well, this issue actually is of as significant a level of importance, because it affects life itself on the planet. Because it affects ecosystems on which the oceans and the land depend for the relationship of the warmth of our earth and the amount of moisture that there is and all of the interactions that occur as a consequence of our climate. Kerry is also the co-author of the last major climate bill anyone tried to pass in the Senate. At its rollout in September 2009, he called the bill "the beginning of one of the most important battles we will ever face, as legislators and as citizens." He's also been a champion of international climate action since way back in 1992, when he attended the first major meeting on it in Rio, Brazil. On the 20th anniversary of the Rio summit this year, Kerry made a floor a statement on the ongoing climate paralysis: Twenty years ago this month, a Republican President of the United States helped bring together all the world's largest economies in Rio to confront the issue of global climate change. The President was unequivocal about the mission. George Herbert Walker Bush said simply, "The United States fully intends to be the world's preeminent leader in protecting the global environment." How dramatic and sad it is that twenty years later, shockingly, we find ourselves in a strange and dangerous place on this issue—a place this former President wouldn't even recognize. When it comes to the challenge of climate change, the falsehood of today's naysayers is only matched by the complacency of our political system ... We should be compelled to fight today’s insidious conspiracy of silence on climate change—a silence that empowers misinformation and mythology to grow where science and truth should prevail. It is a conspiracy that has not just stalled, but demonized any constructive effort to put America in a position to lead the world on this issue, as President Bush promised we would and as Americans have a right to expect we will. That's not to say that Clinton hasn't also expressed interest in climate change; she has. But it seems that it would be far higher up the priorities list for Kerry.

Message.Title: Time names man of the year
Message.Msg: December 19, 2012 Time Names Mitt Romney Man of the Year 1912 Posted by Andy Borowitz NEW YORK (The Borowitz Report)—In an extraordinary gesture of recognition for a losing Presidential nominee, Time magazine today named former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney Man of the Year 1912. In a press release explaining its decision, Time’s editorial board wrote, “Even though his quest for the Presidency was unsuccessful, Mr. Romney’s ideas about foreign policy, taxation, wealth inequality, and women’s rights typified the year 1912 as no one else has.” In giving Mr. Romney the nod, Time said that he beat out such other candidates for Man of the Year 1912 as Tsar Nicholas II of Russia, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany, and Edward Smith, captain of the Titanic. “It was very close between but Romney and the Titanic guy, but we gave it to Romney because it took him slightly longer to sink,” Time wrote. Mr. Romney could not be reached for comment, a spokesman said, because he was travelling around the world visiting his money. .

Topic.Title: ANHEUSER BUSH SAYS ALCOHOL DOESNT CREATE DRUNK DRIVERS

Message.Msg: And $#!+all stupid rightwingnutjob SkinflutePlayer finds the urge IMPOSSIBLE to resist... It's ok though: The CSCO board LOVES to hear his mewling protestations of victory. He's a riot, a laugh a minute. (1) Wanna know what's wrong with the statement "[X] don't/doesn't kill people, PEOPLE kill people?" Well, here's one thing: the logical thrust, if accepted indiscriminately, applies to anything and everything. For example: Hand grenades don't kill people, PEOPLE kill people." "Sarin nerve gas doesn't kill people, PEOPLE kill people." "Thermonuclear weapons don't kill people, PEOPLE kill people."* And you would have us conclude, I suppose, that this is irrefutable evidence of the wrong-headedness of laws against private possession of hand grenades, nerve gas and nukes? Didn't the U.S., at some time in its distant primordial past, fight a couple or three wars over just this issue? (2) Wanna know what's wrong with the further statement (dependent for its force on the underwhelming claim in (1)): "If you're going to try to ban [X] (which, as previously and irrefutably established don't/doesn't kill people, since PEOPLE actually kill people)m then why don't you ban [Y] (which if not entirely innocuous, most people would agree is a LESSER threat than [X])?" This one is pretty easy to deal with, since it's usually (and especially when used for rhetorical effect) based on false equivalency. It fails to acknowledge (or perhaps even to realize) that, while A GREAT MANY things might arguably increase the risk of violence or of accidental injury/death under certain circumstances, and while MANY OTHER things might perhaps with greater or lesser ingenuity be USED as a weapon (a well-placed banana peel, for example), firearms have certain qualitative - and often certain quantitative - characteristics that make them inordinately EFFICIENT at causing injury and/or death, when used as intended, AND IN FACT, THIS IS THEIR PRIMARY PURPOSE (but see (3)). (3) Some also claim (a) that widespread firearm ownership has a deterrent effect, (b) that this deterrent effect is almost entirely a POSITIVE one for society, or at least (c) that the POSITIVE societal impact of this deterrent effect outweighs any concomitant NEGATIVE impact. To which I would say, feel free to continue to argue this, as I'm sure you will, loudly and reflexively. But don't be surprised if your fellow citizens do not feel themselves constrained to agree with your conclusions. -------------------------------- *Or even: "Murderous rampaging cyborgs from the future don't kill people, TWISTED PROGRAMMERS AND CYBERNETICISTS, AND WAYWARD PHYSICISTS SPECIALIZING IN SEEMINGLY UNPRODUCTIVE CLOSED TIMELIKE CURVE RESEARCH kill people."

Message.Title: GOP expert women are dumber, LOL
Message.Msg: Depressing as it is, several of the supposed misogynist myths about female inferiority have been proven true. Women really are worse drivers than men, for example. A study published in 1998 by the Johns Hopkins schools of medicine and public health revealed that women clocked 5.7 auto accidents per million miles driven, in contrast to men's 5.1, even though men drive about 74 percent more miles a year than women. The only good news was that women tended to take fewer driving risks than men, so their crashes were only a third as likely to be fatal. Those statistics were reinforced by a study released by the University of London in January showing that women and gay men perform more poorly than heterosexual men at tasks involving navigation and spatial awareness, both crucial to good driving. (read that carefully, she compares auto accidents per miles driven, then says and men drive more miles!! Hello McFly yes most accidents occur close to the home, all those highway miles men drive in their trucks bringing things to walmart probably reduce their accidents per mile.) The theory that women are the dumber sex -- or at least the sex that gets into more car accidents -- is amply supported by neurological and standardized-testing evidence. Men's and women's brains not only look different, but men's brains are bigger than women's (even adjusting for men's generally bigger body size). One has to admit, if there is an argument for women being dumber then men Charlotte Allen is exhibit number one. LOL

Message.Title: NRA finally issues press release on Sandy Hook shootings
Message.Msg: A.P. news. Northpoint N.C. After days of silence, including taking down its web site, the NRA has finally issued a statement on the Sandy Hook shootings. Speaking in front of a press core of 28 Fox News reporters NRA President David Keene said "We at the NRA share the nations grief at the senseless tragedy that has occurred in Newtown Connecticut, but we ask the country in this time of sadness to react in a reasonable fashion that doesn't back lash against American freedoms. As sad as it is that 20 children and 8 adults perished we need to honor them as patriots that have helped defend our constitutional rights to have fun with our guns. In every war there is collateral damage. As much as we appreciate the suffering of these children's families we rejoice that their deaths have advanced the rights of gun owners." After a few questions Mr. Keene added, "In closing I would like to thank all the NRA members who send in their dues every year, dues that have allowed me and the entire board to become comfortably wealthy. Dues which help us advance the political interests of the gun manufactures that control us and make us wealthy. Without the strength of our lobbying efforts the reaction of the people who value people over guns would overwhelm our rights to have fun with guns."
